Graphical abstract Understanding the influence of pyrolysis oil components on the activity, selectivity and deactivation of nickel-based catalysts during hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) is fundamental to optimise the process for long-term operation and to develop new catalyst formulations. In this study, HDO of a bio-oil light phase and an aqueous solution of phenol (as a model compound) were investigated over fresh and regenerated NiCu/Al2O3 in a batch reactor at 250 and 340°C. The produced upgraded oil over the fresh catalyst contained significant quantities of ketones and phenolic compounds, which were not further converted during hydrotreatment. In the bio-oil environment, the regenerated catalyst showed only marginally lower activity (15% less H2 consumption) in comparison to the fresh one. In contrast, phenol in water was completely converted over fresh NiCu/Al2O3 with high selectivity towards cyclohexanol at 250°C and cyclohexane at 340°C. Once exposed to bio-oil the catalyst no longer showed activity towards phenol conversion in water. Characterization of the spent catalysts indicated the formation of Ni3S2 in addition to coke and alkali metal deposition on the catalyst surface. Other nickel-based catalysts (with different supports and loadings) and two bio-oils with varying sulphur concentration and no minerals were also investigated. Overall the results elucidated that the catalyst activity, selectivity and deactivation of certain reaction paths was mainly determined by the presence of sulphur. By limiting the effects of sulphur poisoning, Ni-catalysts may be considered for the production of fine chemicals, such as ketones and phenols, in addition to fuel synthesis. Keywords Hydrodeoxygenation Pyrolysis oil Nickel catalysts Phenol Deactivation 1 Introduction Energy and chemicals play a key role in improving the quality of life in modern society. However, today their production still remains more associated to fossil fuels rather than renewable resources. Increasing awareness of the future depletion of crude oil reserves and global warming has stimulated the development of new processes involving renewable carbon sources for the production of transportation fuels and chemicals [1]. Biomass represents a valid alternative and in particular the use of lignocellulosic materials not in competition with food crops has been strongly encouraged for ethical reasons [2,3]. Fast pyrolysis of biomass followed by hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) [4–8] to produce upgraded oils could be a solution to accomplish fuel and chemical production in a sustainable and economical way [7,9,10]. While fast pyrolysis is a well-established process from a technological point of view, some aspects of HDO should be further developed for application on an industrial scale [11]. One of the main challenges is related to the HDO catalyst, which should eliminate undesired and reactive oxygen functional groups from the pyrolysis oil compounds, activating molecular hydrogen and promoting the CO cleavage [7]. The ideal HDO catalyst should keep processing costs as low as possible, have a long lifetime, be robust to poisoning and easily regenerable [11,12]. These aspects have not been fully met yet for HDO. A vast amount of studies have focused on the activity of different catalysts (such as the conventional hydrodesulphurization (HDS) catalysts, noble metals and other alternative catalysts) for HDO of model compounds and pyrolysis oil [7,8,13]. However, comparatively little information has been reported on catalyst stability, deactivation, regeneration and long-term operation [4,14–18]. Although some studies reported an operation time over 700h [5,15], the stability of many HDO catalysts is still an open question and more detailed studies are required, especially for alternative systems such as nickel-based catalysts. To the best of the authors’ knowledge, the deactivation of nickel-based catalysts during HDO of pyrolysis oil is an almost untouched subject. Ni-catalysts show good activity in HDO of model compounds and pyrolysis oil [19–22], generating upgraded oils with low oxygen content, high heating value and good stability. However, these upgraded oils contain a lot of phenolic compounds and ketones [19,21,23,24], which according to analogous studies with model compounds [25] should be easily converted. This discrepancy stimulated the interest to understand the influence of pyrolysis oil components on the activity and selectivity of nickel-based catalysts. Pyrolysis oil is a complex mixture and many of its components could potentially deactivate the catalyst [14]. The acidic environment (pH<4) and different functional groups contained in the bio-oil molecules can cause polymerisation, potentially blocking the catalyst active sites by coke deposition on the surface [26]. Water can induce sintering, oxidation of the active metals and destabilisation of the support (e.g. phase change for alumina). Inorganic elements present in small amounts, including sulphur, potassium, calcium and chlorine, can also have a negative impact on the catalytic activity. The influence of sulphur, potassium and chlorine was investigated by Mortenson et al. [14] during HDO of guaiacol over Ni/ZrO2 where the catalyst was irreversibly deactivated by formation of bulk NiS. Adsorption of potassium was found to influence the deoxygenation activity, but not hydrogenation. Chlorine was found to be a reversible poison, decreasing the catalyst activity by competitive adsorption on the active sites. Ardiyanti et al. [19–21] analysed a range of Ni-catalysts used for HDO of pyrolysis oils, including preliminary tests about the feasibility of their regeneration. Coke deposition, metal leaching and sintering were indicated as the main causes of deactivation. This work aims to compare the activity of nickel-based catalysts for HDO using both pyrolysis oil and model compounds, thereby characterising the deactivation processes occurring in the pyrolysis oil in comparison to a pure solvent. For this purpose, NiCu/Al2O3 was tested at 250 and 340°C with a light phase of pyrolysis oil produced from wheat straw, containing small concentrations of inorganics. Following HDO, the spent catalyst was regenerated and further tested with the bio-oil and with phenol in water (as a model compound) in order to identify differences in activity and correlate them to physical and chemical modification of the catalyst structure. Further nickel-based catalysts were characterised after HDO of the light phase and compared with NiCu/Al2O3 to comprehend the influence of the supports, loading and promoters. Finally, in order to clarify the role of sulphur in the deactivation process, NiCu/Al2O3 was tested with bio-oils produced by intermediate pyrolysis of beech wood and wheat straw. Since these bio-oils were treated by hot vapour filtration, sulphur was the only potential inorganic poison. Understanding catalyst deactivation and possible regeneration strategies are fundamental to develop HDO catalysts with better activity, resistance to poisoning and tuneable selectivity. 2 Material and methods 2.1 Characteristics of the pyrolysis oils The feed used for most of the HDO experiments was the light phase of a fast pyrolysis oil (denoted as “light phase”) produced from wheat straw in the bioliq® plant in Karlsruhe. This fraction was formed from spontaneous phase separation of the original bio-oil and mainly consisted of water, sugar derivatives and low molecular weight compounds, as described in Ref. [23]. Besides the main organic components, this fraction also contained a smaller percentage of heteroatoms like N and S and other inorganics (Table 1 ), which can act potentially as poisons. Ion chromatography revealed that sulphur was partly present as sulphate (0.087wt.%) and phosphorus as phosphate (0.066wt.%). Further studies involved the use of two bio-oils produced by intermediate pyrolysis at 450°C in a screw reactor with integrated hot gas filtration (STYX-unit at Institute of Technical Chemistry at Karlsruhe Institute of Technology [27]). Beech wood and wheat straw were used as feedstock and the bio-oils produced were denoted as “beech 450°C” and “straw 450°C” respectively. These bio-oils had a different composition influenced by that of the original biomass, but both contained a low content of minerals due to hot vapour filtration (Table 1). The beech 450°C bio-oil had a low content of sulphur (under the detection limit <0.005%), while the straw 450°C bio-oil had a higher concentration (0.3wt.%). 2.2 Preparation of the catalysts and hydrodeoxygenation experiments The main catalyst under investigation was NiCu/Al2O3, which according to a previous study [23] exhibited the highest HDO activity among a range of nickel-based catalysts. The catalyst was prepared by wet impregnation and consisted of 17.8wt.% Ni and 2.1wt.% Cu supported on θ-alumina (SA31145 provided by Saint Gobain). The BET surface area was 66m2/g. Additional Ni-catalysts were employed in HDO of the light phase to assess the influence of the loading, support and eventual promoters on the deactivation. Further four catalysts were prepared by wet impregnation: Ni/SiO2 (22.0% Ni, BET surface 170m2/g), Ni/ZrO2 (5.8% Ni, BET surface 110m2/g), NiW/AC (3.2% Ni, 7.8% W on Active Carbon, BET surface 1110m2/g) and Ni/TiO2 (5.8% Ni, BET surface 86m2/g). As benchmark a commercial Ni/Al2O3 (METH 134C&CS, nominal loading 20%, BET surface 76m2/g) and Ru/C (Sigma Aldrich, 206180, nominal loading 5%, BET surface 870m2/g) were also tested. For all catalysts, the fraction having a mean Waddel disk diameter less than 100μm was employed for the reaction. More details about catalyst characterisation are reported in Ref. [23]. Hydrotreatment of the light phase over NiCu/Al2O3 and the other catalysts was carried out at 250 and 340°C. At 250°C, HDO was performed in a 200ml-autoclave (max. T=250°C max. P=30MPa, equipped with a magnetically coupled stirrer) using a heating ramp of 5°C/min and reaction time of 4h. At 340°C, HDO was performed in a 200ml-autoclave (max. T=400°C max. P=36MPa, equipped with a gas injection stirrer coupled magnetically) using a heating ramp of 15°C/min and reaction time of 100min (including heating ramp). The stabilisation of the bio-oil in order to avoid polymerisation and excessive coke production was performed during the heating ramp. Hydrotreatment of beech 450°C and straw 450°C bio-oils over NiCu/Al2O3 was also carried out in the latter autoclave using a stabilisation step at 150°C for 1h and a reaction temperature of 350°C for 2h (heating ramp 15°C/min). Similar reaction conditions were employed with respect to other studies [19,20]. The following procedure was used for each reaction. Circa 50g of the light phase/bio-oils and 2.5g of NiCu/Al2O3 were inserted in the autoclave. It was purged with nitrogen and pressurized at room temperature with 8.0MPa H2 for the light phase and 14.0MPa H2 for the other bio-oils. In the model compound studies, 50g phenol solution (10wt.% in H2O) were used. The heating program was switched on and the stirrer speed set at 1000rpm. Once the reaction was completed, the reactor was quenched and the products collected and separated by centrifugation as described in Ref. [23]. The catalyst impregnated by residue of the liquid products was washed with acetone, filtrated and dried under vacuum. The final products consisted of an upgraded oil, an aqueous phase, gases and solids. The spent catalysts were analysed by several techniques described below. For regeneration, the catalysts used for the same experiment replicate with the pyrolysis oils were mixed and calcined in air at 500°C (to eliminate carbon), then reduced at 500°C (25% H2 in N2, total flow 2.6 NL/min). Experiments with the regenerated catalyst with pyrolysis oils or phenol in water were performed again using the same conditions described for the fresh catalyst. 2.3 Methods for characterisation of bio-oils and upgraded products C, H and N content in the upgraded products was determined by elemental analysis (CHN628, Leco), while oxygen was calculated by difference. Karl Fischer titration (Titrando 841, Metrohm) was employed to determine the water content in the products. Inorganic elements in the bio-oils or in the aqueous phase were detected by Inductively Coupled Plasma Optical Emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES, Agilent 725 ICP-OES Spectrometer). Quantitative 1H NMR was employed to calculate the concentration of protons associated to the chemical shift range typical of some functional groups. Samples were diluted 1:10 in CD3OD containing TMSP-d4 (sodium 3-trimethylsilyl-2,2′,3,3′-tetradeuteropropionate) as internal standard (∼2g/L). NMR measurement parameters are described in Ref. [23]. GC–MS (HP G1800A, GCD) was employed for qualitative characterization of the upgraded oil and aqueous phase. The device was equipped with a Stabilwax (Restek) column. The sample was dissolved 1:10 in methanol and 1μl was injected with a split ratio 20:1 (injector temperature 250°C, He carrier). The oven program was: 5min at 40°C, heating rate 8°C/min until 250°C, 10min at 250°C. Thermogravimetric Analysis (TGA, Netzsch STA 409) was performed to determine the coking tendency of the upgraded oil [19]. Measurements were made under N2 atmosphere with a heating ramp of 10°C/min from 30 to 900°C, and held for 30min. For the analysis of the gaseous phase, a 7890A Agilent gas chromatograph was used. It was equipped with two columns (Restek 57096 Hayesep Q and Restek Molsieve 5A) and TCD/FID detectors. 100μl gas was injected at 250°C with split ratio 28:1 (He as carrier gas). The oven temperature was set as follows: 50°C for 10min, heating rate 3°C/min until 90°C, 20°C/min until 150°C (held for 16min), 50°C/min until 230°C, 10min at 230°C. 2.4 Characterisation methods for analysis of the active metals in the fresh, spent and regenerated catalysts The metal content of the fresh catalyst was determined by ICP-OES after dissolution in 6ml HCl conc. and 2ml HNO3 conc. in a microwave (max temperature 240°C and max 60bar for 45min, 600W). The crystalline structure was investigated by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) using an X́Pert PRO MPD instrument (PANanalytical GmbH) equipped with a copper anode (CuKα 1.54060Å). The signal acquisition was recorded at step size of 0.017°. The average crystal size was estimated by Scherrer equation [28] using a shape factor K=0.9. X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) of nickel (NiK edge 8333eV, transmission mode) and copper (CuK edge 8988eV, fluorescence mode) was measured at the XAS beamline of the ANKA synchrotron (Karlsruhe, Germany). Catalyst pellets were prepared by dilution of the fresh and spent NiCu/Al2O3 at 250 and 340°C in cellulose (1:4) and measured ex situ. In the case of spent NiCu/Al2O3 at 250°C, an in situ reduction was performed. The catalyst was diluted 1:2 with alumina, sieved (100–200μm sieve fraction) and placed in a quartz capillary (1.5mm diameter) [29]. Reduction was performed under a flow of 5% H2 in He (50ml/min), with a heating ramp of 5°C/min until 500°C using a hot air blower (Gas Blower GSB-1300, FMB Oxford [30]). The spectrum presented in this work was recorded once the sample was cooled to room temperature. XANES spectra were analysed with Athena 0.8.054 (Ifeffit package [31]), and linear combination fitting (LCF) performed using NiO and Ni commercial catalyst standards. For the characterisation of the catalyst surface, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed ex situ on a pellet of the compressed catalyst. The XPS measurements were performed using an Al Kα (nonmonochromatic, 1486.68eV) X-ray spectrophotometer with a VG Scienta R4000 electron energy analyser. The instrument was calibrated with the reference peaks of Au4f7/2 (84.00eV) and Ag3d5/2 (368.26eV). Surface composition and concentrations were determined after the subtraction of a Shirley background. A product of Gaussian and Lorentzian functions was used for fitting the peaks and the integrated area was corrected by the relative sensitivity factor. To eliminate the influence of surface charging, the binding energies were corrected assuming that C1s line of adventitious carbon is at 285eV. Fresh and spent (250°C) samples of NiCu/Al2O3 were analysed by Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) on a FEI Tecnai F20 ST TEM (200kV), equipped with a field emission gun and EDAX EDS X-ray spectrometer (Si(Li) detecting unit, super ultrathin window, active area 30mm2, resolution 135eV (at 5.9 keV)). For TEM and STEM analysis, the catalysts were suspended in ethanol. A small droplet of the dispersed catalyst was deposited on an amorphous carbon-coated 200mesh Al grid and eventually air dried. Fresh and spent (340°C) samples of NiCu/Al2O3 were analysed by FEI Titan 80–300 microscope (300kV). The powder samples of the catalysts were directly dispersed on molybdenum grids covered with holey carbon film. Morphology of the catalysts was characterised by high angle annular dark-field (HAADF) scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) and its composition information were acquired by single EDAX S-UTW EDX detector. Quantification analysis of EDX spectra and STEM-EDX spectrum imaging were carried out by using TEM Image & Analysis (TIA 4.7 SP3 version) software. The total specific surface area of the catalyst was determined by nitrogen physisorption (Belsorp Mini II) at 77K and calculated by applying BET theory in the fitting range between 0.05-0.30 p/p0 (12 points). Leaching of the catalyst was monitored by analysing the aqueous phase by ICP-OES (Agilent 725 ICP-OES Spectrometer). 2.5 Deposition of organic and inorganic material on the catalyst surface C deposition, S and N content were monitored by elemental analysis (Vario EL Cube, Elementar). To investigate the persistency of the carbon deposit, TGA (Netzsch STA 409) was performed using ∼200mg sample in 0.1MPa synthetic air (21% O2 in N2) with the following program: heating ramp 10°C/min from 20 to 105°C, hold at 105°C for 1h, heating ramp 10°C/min from 105°C to 1100°C, hold at 1100°C for 1h. The chemical nature of the carbon deposit was investigated by Attenuated Total Reflectance IR (ATR-IR, Varian 660-IR FT-IR) with a diamond element. Spectra were recorded in the range 4000–230cm−1 with resolution of 1cm−1. The presence of different inorganic and organic elements on the surface was monitored by scanning electron microscopy energy dispersive X-ray analysis (SEM-EDX, DSM 982 Gemini, Carl Zeiss Ltd) equipped with a field emission gun and secondary ion, backscatter and transmission detectors. The EDX unit is constituted of a Si(Li) X-ray detector (INCA Penta FET; 30mm2 crystal size; Oxford Instruments). The approximate superficial concentration detected by SEM-EDX is reported for a ROI (Region of Interest) of circa 1mm2. For analysing the deposits on the surface of the catalyst, Time-of-Flight Secondary Ion Mass Spectrometry (ToF-SIMS) was performed on a pellet prepared from the catalyst powder (see XPS section). The TOF·SIMS5 instrument (ION-TOF GmbH), was equipped with a Bi cluster primary ion source and a reflectron type time-of-flight analyser. For further information see Electronic Supplementary Information (ESI). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 HDO activity and selectivity of fresh and regenerated NiCu/Al2O3 Fresh and regenerated NiCu/Al2O3 were tested at 250 and 340°C in the HDO reaction to determine the effect of pyrolysis oil on the catalyst activity and selectivity. The fresh catalyst showed good catalytic activity (on dry basis comparable with Ardiyanti et al. [19]) during HDO of the light phase of pyrolysis oil produced from wheat straw (see hydrogen consumption and deoxygenation degree (D.O.D.) in Table 2 ). The regenerated NiCu/Al2O3 had similar catalytic performance, reporting a H2 consumption at 250°C and 340°C corresponding to 87% and 84% of that of the fresh catalyst and a comparable D.O.D. (Table 2). The mass balance and the products composition were comparable between the experiment with fresh and regenerated catalyst (Table 2). Only small differences were observed in the mass balance at 250°C, due a different compound distribution in the product phases, resulting in a higher carbon recovery in the aqueous phase for the fresh catalyst. HDO at 250°C produced upgraded oils with higher density than the aqueous phases, while at 340°C the opposite situation was observed. The deoxygenation degree of the upgraded oils was slightly inferior in the case of the regenerated catalyst, but still comparable. Gas production was enhanced over the regenerated catalyst, probably due to cracking reactions favoured in this environment (see gas composition in Table 2). Generally the composition of the upgraded oils and aqueous phases were similar for the experiments with fresh and regenerated catalyst, as observed by 1H NMR and GC–MS. Smaller differences were detected for the products at 340°C than at 250°C. A slightly higher concentration in protons associated to alkane groups (0.5-1.5ppm, 1H NMR spectra in Fig. 1 ) were detected in the upgraded oils produced over fresh catalyst. The main signal of the upgraded oils belongs to protons alpha to carboxylic/carbonylic groups and unsaturated compounds (1.5-3.0ppm): this signal was higher at 250°C for the regenerated catalyst, while at 340°C for the fresh one. Protons alpha to alcohol or ether/ester groups (3.0-4.3ppm) had generally a low contribution, with higher concentration at 250°C for the fresh catalyst and comparable at 340°C. Aromatic protons (6.0-8.5ppm) were not affected by the catalyst recycle showing similar concentration in both cases. GC–MS confirmed the 1H NMR results (chromatograms reported in ESI, Fig. S1-S2). Production of ketones was more accentuated at 340°C than 250°C and similar compositions were recorded between the experiment with fresh and regenerated catalyst. Hydrocarbons were not detected in significant concentration. All aromatic compounds had similar concentrations, except for phenol at 250°C, where the regenerated catalyst showed less conversion (concentration calculated by GC-FID in the upgraded oil for fresh NiCu/Al2O3 0.7wt.% and for the regenerated catalyst 1.2wt.%; at 340°C 0.6wt.% for both oils). One of the main differences between the experiments at 250°C and 340°C was the conversion of methoxy-phenols (like guaiacol and syringol) and the formation of alkyl-phenols at higher temperature. Using fresh NiCu/Al2O3 in HDO of phenol (10wt.% in water), mainly cyclohexanol (selectivity 98.8%) was obtained at 250°C and cyclohexane at 340°C (selectivity 85%, details on Fig. S3, ESI). Strikingly, the regenerated NiCu/Al2O3 (after use with the bio-oil) could no longer convert phenol in water, indicating that its activity was altered by its preceding use with the pyrolysis oil fraction, causing permanent deactivation and inhibition of this reaction pathway (discussed in detail in the following sections). Actually, phenol was not significantly converted either during HDO of the light phase, showing analogies to the studies with model compounds. This suggests that pyrolysis oil immediately affected the activity and the selectivity of the fresh and regenerated NiCu/Al2O3, favouring production of ketones and preserving phenol derivatives from hydrogenation and HDO. This kind of selectivity of nickel catalysts was already reported in other studies [19–21], but no explanations for this behaviour were offered. Although some reaction pathways over the catalyst were inhibited (like phenol and ketones conversion), the upgraded oils obtained from the light phase showed a higher quality, and a lower level of oxygen compared to the feed (40.0wt.% dry basis): 18.2 and 19.3% at 250°C and 14.3 and 16.2% at 340°C (dry basis, Table 2) for the upgraded oils produced over fresh and regenerated catalysts respectively. In addition, the upgraded oils showed a low coking tendency: the carbon residue measured by TGA at 900°C was 11.9% at 250°C and 3.0 at 340°C. In this last case, probably fractionated distillation could be considered for product separation. The catalyst selectivity observed could in principle be used to develop a route for production of fine chemicals from pyrolysis oil (e.g. phenols and ketones) instead of fuels, increasing the economic value of the products and using less energy. The comparable activity of the regenerated catalyst with the fresh one provides a preliminary indication regarding the feasibility for long-term or repeated use. 3.2 Characterisation of the active metals in the fresh, spent and regenerated catalysts In order to understand which parameters influence the activity and selectivity of NiCu/Al2O3 a detailed characterisation of catalyst before the reaction (fresh), after the reaction (spent) and after regeneration was performed using a combination of XRD, XAS, XPS and STEM-EDX. XRD gave information about the crystalline structure of the catalyst. In fresh NiCu/Al2O3 only the reflections of metallic nickel were observed after reduction (Fig. 2 ). They appeared at a lower angle compared to a metallic nickel standard (44.25° vs 44.51° for the reflection (111)) suggesting that copper was integrated in the nickel lattice forming an alloy (Vegard’s law). Nickel oxide reflections were present only in the calcined NiCu/Al2O3. In the spent and regenerated NiCu/Al2O3, metallic nickel reflections were also observed. Applying the Scherrer equation to the reflection Ni(111), the average crystallite size was estimated to be 8nm in the fresh catalyst, 10nm in the spent catalyst after the reaction at 250°C and 12nm after the reaction at 340°C. After regeneration, the average crystallite size increased to 14nm (250°C), while a separation into two reflections (44.21 and 44.52°) was observed for the catalyst used at 340°C. The reflection at 44.21° was attributed to nickel-copper alloy and the smaller one at 44.52° to pure metallic nickel, generated probably by a tendency for the two metals to separate at higher temperatures (supported also by STEM-EDX, see later). Small typical reflections of Ni3S2 at 49.86° and 50.26° were observed only in the spent catalyst at 340°C, but they disappeared after regeneration. The formation of Ni3S2 could explain the nickel-copper separation, indicating that after regeneration nickel remained segregated and did not recombine with copper. Complementary information about the oxidation state of the crystalline-amorphous phase of nickel and copper was provided by XAS. The XANES spectrum of the fresh NiCu/Al2O3 was treated by LCF using Ni and NiO standards (Fig. 3 a), revealing a composition of 73 and 27 at.% respectively. As the catalyst was measured ex situ, the oxidised component probably resulted from a surface layer formed during contact with air. Copper was more oxidised than nickel with a composition of Cu0 (45%) and CuO (55%) determined by LCF. Information derived from EXAFS spectra of the fresh catalyst are reported and discussed in Table S1 in ESI. After the reaction at 250°C, nickel in the spent catalyst was slightly more reduced compared to the fresh one (80% Ni, 20% NiO, Fig. 3b). This could indicate larger particles or formation of coke and other mineral deposits on the surface that prevented reoxidation in air. Copper was also more reduced after the reaction (84% Cu and 16% CuO). In the case of the spent catalyst at 340°C a similar oxidation level for nickel was observed as in the fresh catalyst: 69% Ni, 31% NiO (Fig. 3c), while copper remained generally more reduced at 77% Cu and 23% CuO. Note that the quality of the fit was gradually worse from the fresh catalyst to the spent one at 340°C. This could suggest the presence of another species in limited concentration, such as adsorbed sulphur on nickel or Ni3S2 observed previously by XRD (reference spectra in [32]). After in situ reduction of the spent catalyst at 250°C, the oxidised component was reduced and the spectrum was fitted only with the metallic nickel reference (Fig. 3d). Therefore if an additional species was present, it was either removed during regeneration or was below the detection limit. Information about the surface composition of the catalyst was provided by XPS. Mainly NiO (Ni 2p3/2 855.9eV) was identified in all the catalysts (Fig. 4 a, b). A less intense peak was associated to metallic nickel (Ni 2p3/2 852.3eV), which exhibited a slightly higher intensity for the spent catalyst at 250°C, confirming the results found by XAS. According to the attenuation length of the Ni 2p electrons, the information extracted from XPS are related approximatively the top 1nm surface layer [33]. In line with the conclusion by XAS, this indicates that NiO was localised on the external surface of reduced nickel particles, forming a passivation layer that was not limited only to a single monolayer, but to 4–7 layers as reported in literature [34]. Generally, the complex peak structure due to satellite peaks generated by shake-up processes [35,36] makes the interpretation of XPS spectra of nickel species difficult. The binding energy of Ni0 observed was 852.3eV for Ni 2p3/2 and 869.7eV for Ni 2p1/2 with spin-orbit splitting of 17.3eV. In comparison to bulk nickel (Ni 2p3/2 852.6eV), a shift to lower energy for Ni 2p was recorded, probably due to the alloy formed with copper that increments its electron density [37]. The NiO related binding energy were located at 855.9eV and at 873.3eV, in agreement with literature [35], and satellite peaks at 861.4eV and 879.6eV. Ni3S2 (Ni 2p3/2) was not unambiguously identified in the spent catalysts. In this case, the binding energy for nickel should be at 853.0eV [38], but this contribution could be overlapped by the other peaks, if it is not present in high amount. The XPS sensitivity for sulphur was too low to detect any signal in the spent catalyst at 250°C, but the presence of sulphide was detected in the catalyst used at 340°C with a peak at 162.1eV. The detection limit of XPS is at best 0.1 at.% and alternative surface sensitive techniques should be employed for detecting sulphur, like ToF-SIMS, which can detect in the ppm range [39]. Cu2+ was undoubtedly present in the catalysts and easily recognizable from the shake-up peak between 938 and 947eV [35] (Fig. 4c,d). The binding energies of Cu0 and Cu+ are similar and therefore it is difficult to discriminate these species by XPS. As confirmed by XAS, Cu0 in the fresh catalyst was lower than in the spent one (932.0eV Cu2p3/2). A shift related to copper to lower binding energies compared to the bulk material was also observed in literature in the case of alloy with nickel [35,37]. The ratio Cu/Ni for the surface atomic concentration calculated by XPS was in the range 0.20-0.28 (Table 3 ), which was higher than the values expected by the bulk composition (circa 0.1). This suggests that copper tends to segregate on the surface, reducing therefore the interfacial surface energy [35,37,40]. The Ni/Al and Cu/Al ratio (Table 3) varied after the reaction and the ratio Cu/Ni decreased only slightly. The surface area occupied by nickel and copper decreased, indicating that a structural change of the catalyst happened, which could be justified by sintering, changing of the particle shape or covering by other contaminants. STEM images of the fresh NiCu/Al2O3 showed a relatively broad distribution of nanoparticles from 5 to 20nm in the fresh catalyst (Fig. 5 ). Quantified compositions from STEM-EDX spectra acquired in different areas of the fresh NiCu/Al2O3 indicated that the ratio Cu/Ni was on average constant and approximately 1:9, with qualitatively higher concentration of copper on the nanoparticle exterior. The particle size of the spent catalyst at 250°C slightly increased compared to the fresh catalyst, indicating sintering in a marginal way, as confirmed also by XRD. In the spent catalyst at 340°C (Fig. S4, ESI) some regions showed particle aggregation (as an effect of sintering). Quantified compositions from STEM-EDX spectra acquired in different areas showed that the ratio Cu/Ni was not anymore constant at 1:9 and nickel-rich and copper-rich regions were detected. This indicated a tendency towards phase separation at higher temperature, also identified previously by XRD, where two reflections were detected instead of one for Ni (111). No significant leaching was detected for the active metal, probably due to the reducing reaction atmosphere, which stabilised nickel in the metallic form. 0.8% of the nickel contained in the catalyst was found in solution at 250°C and 0.24% at 340°C. The higher amount of leaching at lower temperature could be a result of the longer reaction time or because higher temperatures together with high H2 pressure preserved the reduced form of the catalyst, avoiding its oxidation. In summary, NiCu/Al2O3 (Ni 17.8%, Cu 2.1%) was constituted of nickel-copper nanoparticles alloyed in an average ratio of 9:1, enriched on the surface by copper. The active metals were affected by surface passivation when exposed to air, with a layer of oxide estimated to be1–2nm thick. The active particles of the spent catalysts at 250°C and 340°C were affected slightly by sintering, rearrangement of the metal ratio of the alloy, and sulphur adsorption forming the structure Ni3S2. 3.3 Deposition and adsorption of various species on the catalyst surface Polymerisation and coking are two potential routes of catalyst deactivation, which were investigated by elemental analysis, SEM-EDX and ATR-IR spectroscopy. Carbon content analysis was performed by elemental analysis (C, H, N, S) and SEM-EDX and the results are compared in Table 4 . SEM-EDX showed higher values, suggesting that the coke deposition was mainly on the surface. In addition, carbon distribution on the surface was not homogenous and varied slightly depending on the region analysed. Since the approximate Ni surface concentration calculated by SEM-EDX decreased when carbon was on the surface and it was restored after regeneration, this suggests that carbon lowered the accessibility of Ni during the reaction. Higher carbon depositions were monitored at 250°C than 340°C, probably due to a lower hydrogenation activity at lower temperature and the prevailing of polymerization reactions [41], associated to a less effective stirring setup. According to TGA analysis of the spent catalysts (Fig. S5, ESI), coke could be completely removed by oxidation below 500°C, therefore this temperature was chosen for calcination and reduction during the regeneration step. Coke deposition on the spent catalysts was further analysed by ATR-IR spectroscopy in order to characterise its chemical nature. Similar groups were detected for the carbonaceous species formed at 250°C and 340°C over the catalysts and in the blank experiment (Fig. 6 ). The IR bands were relatively weak, due to the low amount of carbon compared to the catalyst inorganic components. Stretching bands between 1720 and 1650cm−1 were attributed to CO of ketones, esters and carboxylic acids, and in the range 1600–1500cm−1 to symmetric stretching frequencies of COO- and CC of aromatic groups and alkenes. Broad bands in the range 1290–1000cm−1 belonged to stretching vibration of alcohols, phenols and ethers [42,43], and in the range 900–700cm−1 to bending in the aromatic ring. The chemical structure of the coke deposited on the catalyst showed more analogies with humic matter than fossil coal. Analysis by ToF-SIMS identified tropylium fragments (C7H7 +) on the spent catalyst surface, which is an indication of the partial aromatic character of the carbon deposits. According to the depth profile, it was removed after the first sputter and also after regeneration. Therefore, carbon deposition could be easily removed by oxidation during the regeneration step, but it could reduce the activity of the catalyst during HDO, blocking access to the active sites. However, it was demonstrated in industrial hydrotreatment processes [44] that the reduction in the catalyst activity by carbon deposition reached a plateau after a period of operation and after that the activity remained constant. Another deactivation pathway is related to deposition of inorganic elements, like S, Mg, P, Cl, K, Ca on the surface, which could not be removed by the regeneration (Tables 3, 4). Calcium was present in the highest concentration on the surface among these elements. Some calcium salts were even detected by XRD, like Ca3(PO4)2, CaSO4 and CaO, which deposited unselectively on the surface, probably as a consequence of the decrease of the solvent polarity and solubility at high temperatures. The catalyst could act as a nucleation centre for precipitation of these salts. The surface atomic concentration of calcium and potassium calculated by XPS was comparable or superior to that of nickel (Table 3), indicating that they could modify substantially the catalyst activity. However, Ca and K were localised inhomogeneously mainly on the support surface instead of covering nickel, as observed by integration of different regions by SEM-EDX and STEM-EDX (Table 5 ) and mapping by ToF-SIMS (Fig. S6, ESI). According to the depth profile followed by ToF-SIMS (Fig. S7, ESI), K and Ca concentrations were higher on the surface of the spent and regenerated catalyst, and they decreased upon sample erosion in the dynamic SIMS experiment shown in Fig. S7a–c. Calcium could have an ambivalent effect on the catalyst activity, since it can act as a poison or it can enhance the resistance of nickel against sulphur [13], e.g. weakening the formation of nickel sulphide for electronic reasons [45]. In addition, Ca could promote the reduction of nickel sulphide to metallic nickel [46], since the formation of CaSO4 or CaS is thermodynamically more favoured than NiS or NiSO4. This could help in preserving the catalyst from deactivation and prolong the catalyst lifespan. Potassium could cause reversible poisoning, having an influence on HDO as described by Ref. [14]. This effect was not clear in this work, but K and Ca could decrease the catalyst activity due to fouling on the surface, which would present problems for continuous operation, as observed in HDS processes [44]. This problem could be minimised by using hot vapour filtrated pyrolysis oil, which contains low level of minerals. ToF-SIMS confirmed that the concentration of the main constituents of the catalyst (Ni, Cu, Al) was lower on the surface of the spent and regenerated catalyst compared to the fresh one, due to the presence of coke and other minerals that cover the surface (Fig. 7 ). Different sulphur ions were detected (Fig. 7), confirming the presence of sulphur species on the surface, such as sulphate and sulphide detected by XRD. As demonstrated also by elemental analysis and SEM-EDX, sulphur was not completely removed after the regeneration. Na, Mg, Cl were also present on the surface, but in lower concentrations than K and Ca. For the spent catalyst at 340°C, quantified results of STEM-EDX spectra acquired in different regions showed regions richer in nickel and others with a higher ratio of Cu/Ni, indicating a tendency for the alloy to rearrange and separate. Alkali and alkaline earth metals were in relatively high concentration compared to nickel and not homogeneously distributed. The elements distribution of single particle is detected by STEM-EDX spectrum imaging (Fig. 8 ) and quantified compositions of whole particle summary in Table 5. The composition maps show there are a few S, Mg, Fe, P and K elements in nanoparticle and Ni and Cu maps have similar distribution. Sulphur was the main element with a relevant concentration localised in nickel nanoparticle (Table 5, Fig. 8), indicating probably the formation of Ni3S2, even detected in some samples by XRD. The concentration of other elements within the nanoparticle was lower compared to analysing an extended region, indicating their tendency to deposit preferentially on the alumina support. Considering that the number of sulphur atoms was 9–19% that of nickel in the nanoparticles, Ni3S2 should constitute a thin outer layer, as often reported in literature [26,44,47–49]. The formation of sulphide as a surface layer or bulk is known to be dependent on the sulphur content in the feed, the hydrogen pressure and the operating temperature [47]. 3.4 Comparison with other nickel-based catalysts Various additional nickel-based catalysts were tested under the same conditions as NiCu/Al2O3. Despite the different support and loadings, they exhibited the same selectivity towards ketones and phenolic components at 250°C and 340°C (Ref. [23], Fig. S8). Ru/C was more selective towards alcohols. The spent catalysts were analysed in order to monitor any physical and chemical changes. XRD (Fig. S9-S14, ESI) showed a slight sintering, more pronounced at 340°C than 250°C. The fresh Ni/Al2O3 (Fig. S10, ESI) had an average crystal size of 15nm (calculated by Scherrer equation) and after the reaction at 250 and 340°C it increased to 17nm. Ni/SiO2 (Fig. S11, ESI) showed the same average dimension of 20nm before and after the reaction at 250°C and it increased to 22nm at 340°C. The fresh Ni/ZrO2 (Fig. S12, ESI) and Ni/TiO2 (Fig. S14, ESI) did not show any nickel reflections, suggesting the presence of an amorphous phase or very small crystallites. After the HDO reaction, small reflections appeared indicating some sintering, but the low signal intensity did not allow estimation of the crystallite size. Similarly, also Ru/C showed low intensity reflections only after the reaction at 340°C (Fig. S9, ESI). NiW/AC (Fig. S13, ESI) showed a peculiar phase transition, changing from a lattice mixture of tungsten oxide to CaWO4 after HDO at 340°C. Therefore it is not recommended to use tungsten oxide if in the bio-oil feed calcium is present. In most of the catalysts, small reflections of Ni3S2 were identifiable (typically at 2θ=21.81°, 49.86° and 50.26°). As asserted previously, Ni3S2 may be present despite the lack of observed reflections, but possibly amorphous or not within the crystallite size range visible to XRD. In all the catalysts reflections associated to calcium salts, including CaSO4, Ca3(PO4)2 and CaO were detected. Generally, the information gained about mineral deposition monitored by SEM-EDX was similar to those of NiCu/Al2O3 (Table S2-S3, ESI). Similar concentration of sulphur and other inorganics was detected on the catalyst surface. ROIs with higher concentration of calcium were often associated to sulphur. K and Ca were deposited in higher concentrations after the reaction at 340°C than at 250°C, probably due to the change of polarity and solubility dependent on the temperature. As observed and explained previously, also in other catalysts, carbon deposition (Table 6 ) was lower at 340 than at 250°C. The catalysts supported on alumina showed lower carbon deposition compared to other supports, probably because theta alumina and corundum was used instead of gamma alumina, which can induce polymerization with its acidic characteristics. Alumina could present the disadvantage of converting to boehmite in the presence of water. In the HDO conditions used, alumina was stable, but it would be recommendable for long-term hydrotreatment experiments to choose a support less sensitive to water. Its resistivity in this work could be also justified by the deposition of alkali and alkaline earth metals, modifying the acidity and reactivity of alumina and offering a kind of protective layer. Elemental analysis (Table 6) confirmed that carbon and nitrogen were mainly removed from the catalyst surface after regeneration, while sulphur was persistent. The leaching was lower at 340°C than at 250°C as observed previously in the case of NiCu/Al2O3, but in general it was limited to low amounts. The catalyst surface area measured by BET was sensitive to deposition of coke and minerals (Table 6). Deposited coke probably blocked the access to the pores, decreasing the surface area of the spent catalyst substantially. After the regeneration, some catalysts like those supported on alumina and zirconia could almost recover the original surface area and porosity volume, while the others only partially, suggesting irreversible morphological changes. In the case of the catalysts supported on carbon, the reduction in the surface area was drastic, indicating that supports with micropores may be more sensitive to pyrolysis oil than those with macro- or mesopores. In general, similar effects on the activity and selectivity during HDO and similar deactivation process were detected on different nickel-based catalysts. Sulphur was the only poison that appeared directly bonded to nickel and plausibly it has the main effect on the activity and selectivity of the catalyst. However, other minerals (especiallyK and Ca) were present in the light phase and although they were deposited mainly on the catalyst support, it could not be excluded that they had an influence on the products. 3.5 Comparison with other pyrolysis oils from different feedstocks In order to elucidate the role of sulphur, beech 450°C and straw 450°C bio-oils (cf. Section 2.1) were used. Since the pyrolysis vapours were filtered downstream to this process, these oils did not contain minerals (e.g.K and Ca) or char. The hydrotreatment of these two bio-oils over fresh NiCu/Al2O3 produced a relatively high percentage of ketones and phenols (Fig. 9 , Fig. S15, ESI), showing similar results to the previous experiment with the light phase. From the XRD of the spent catalyst (Fig. 10 ), NiCu/Al2O3 used with beech 450°C bio-oil did not exhibit significant modifications compared to the fresh form, while intense Ni3S2 reflections were detected after the catalyst was used with the wheat straw bio-oil. The sulphur detected by elemental analysis (Table 6) on the spent catalyst used with beech 450°C bio-oil was 0.4wt.% (although the concentration in the feed was under the detection limit) and with straw 450°C bio-oil 2.6wt.%. The regeneration of NiCu/Al2O3 used with beech wood bio-oil was similar to that observed in the previous study with the light phase. On the contrary, the NiCu/Al2O3 used with wheat straw bio-oil formed NiO and NiSO4 during calcination (favoured thermodynamically from Ni3S2 [50]) and the following reduction produced mainly Ni0, which was strongly sintered (circa 47nm) and in lower amounts Ni3S2 (sulphur on surface 2.0wt.%). The sintering was enhanced by the lower melting point of nickel sulphide, promoting mobility and aggregation of the nanoparticles at lower temperature (according to the Tamman and Hüttig temperature [44]). When the regenerated catalyst from beech wood bio-oil was used again with the same bio-oil and conditions, the hydrogen consumption was 206 NL/kg in comparison to 239 NL/kg of the fresh one. The activity lowered at 86% of the original value, in a similar way as observed in Section 3.1. The composition of the upgraded oils produced over the fresh and regenerated catalyst was similar (Table 7 ) and both contained a significant concentration of ketones and phenolic compounds, as observed by 1H NMR (Fig. 9) and GC–MS (Fig. S15, ESI). On the other hand, using the regenerated catalysts in HDO of phenol in aqueous solution, no conversion was detected, despite sulphur being in lower concentration. Since no other minerals were deposited on the catalyst surface, this confirmed the role of sulphur on changing the activity and selectivity of nickel-based catalysts. The formation of Ni3S2 may result in restructuring of the catalyst surface and a variation of electron density in the active metal. As a consequence, the ability of nickel to adsorb and activate hydrogen and other substrates is modified. It is known that the adsorption of hydrogen on Ni3S2 is reduced in comparison to Ni [26]. However, Ni3S2 is still active for olefin hydrogenation, but not for aromatic compounds [51], analogously to what was observed in this study in the case of olefins and phenol compounds. Hence, the adsorption and activation of the bio-oil molecules probably changed considerably between Ni and Ni3S2, explaining why only the deactivation of some reaction pathways was observed. 4 Conclusions The conversion of phenolic compounds over NiCu/Al2O3 strongly depends on whether they were treated in water as model compounds or in bio-oil and over fresh or regenerated catalysts. After HDO of the bio-oil, different inorganics including S, K, Mg, Ca and P, and coke deposited on the catalyst surface. Coke can be easily removed by regeneration (calcination and reduction at 500°C), while the inorganics are persistent. Sulphur was directly bonded to the nickel nanoparticles forming Ni3S2, while the other elements were mainly adsorbed on the support. Similar selectivity and elemental surface composition was observed for a range of nickel-based catalysts. The use of bio-oil containing only sulphur as contaminant and no minerals confirmed that sulphur has the main influence on the activity and selectivity of HDO of bio-oil. Despite the deactivation process, the upgraded oils produced by nickel catalysts had lower oxygen content than the original pyrolysis oil. Therefore if the superficial deactivation from sulphur can be controlled and maintained, the catalyst can be used for the production of phenolic components and ketones. In this way, the hydrotreating process can potentially be addressed to the production of chemicals instead of fuels, increasing the economic value of the products. Future studies should aim to monitor the stability of nickel-based catalysts on a long-term and consider the feasibility of distillation or extraction to separate the products. coredata.dc:description: Understanding the influence of pyrolysis oil components on the activity, selectivity and deactivation of nickel-based catalysts during hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) is fundamental to optimise the process for long-term operation and to develop new catalyst formulations. In this study, HDO of a bio-oil light phase and an aqueous solution of phenol (as a model compound) were investigated over fresh and regenerated NiCu/Al2O3 in a batch reactor at 250 and 340°C. The produced upgraded oil over the fresh catalyst contained significant quantities of ketones and phenolic compounds, which were not further converted during hydrotreatment. In the bio-oil environment, the regenerated catalyst showed only marginally lower activity (15% less H2 consumption) in comparison to the fresh one. In contrast, phenol in water was completely converted over fresh NiCu/Al2O3 with high selectivity towards cyclohexanol at 250°C and cyclohexane at 340°C. Once exposed to bio-oil the catalyst no longer showed activity towards phenol conversion in water. Characterization of the spent catalysts indicated the formation of Ni3S2 in addition to coke and alkali metal deposition on the catalyst surface. Other nickel-based catalysts (with different supports and loadings) and two bio-oils with varying sulphur concentration and no minerals were also investigated. Overall the results elucidated that the catalyst activity, selectivity and deactivation of certain reaction paths was mainly determined by the presence of sulphur. By limiting the effects of sulphur poisoning, Ni-catalysts may be considered for the production of fine chemicals, such as ketones and phenols, in addition to fuel synthesis.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of pyrolysis oil components on the activity and selectivity of nickel-based catalysts during hydrotreatment
